bestBHT.bht: Cæsarea, a significant town in Palestine, had a mixed population of Gentiles and Jews. Cornelius, a devout centurion from the Italian band stationed there, was known for his sincerity in embracing the worship of the true God while eschewing idols. Despite serving in a corrupt environment as a soldier, Cornelius displayed commendable virtues and treated others with courtesy and upright conduct. The preparation of Peter's work and miracles in Lydda and elsewhere paved the way for the unfolding of this significant event.

Henry Alford: CÆSAREA is between Joppa and Dora, 68 Roman miles from Jerusalem according to the Jerusalem Itinerary, 75 according to Josephus,—36 miles from Ptolemais (a day’s journey, Acts xxi. 8),—30 from Joppa;—one of the largest towns in Palestine, with an excellent haven, built by Herod the Great, and called Sebastos (Augustus) in honour of Cæsar."
It was chiefly inhabited by Gentiles, but there were also many thousand Jewish inhabitants.
a centurion] The subordinate officer commanding the sixth part of a cohort, or half a maniple. of the band called the Italian band] i.e. of a cohort levied in Italy, not in Syria.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: the Italian band—a cohort of Italians, as distinguished from native soldiers, quartered at Cæsarea, probably as a bodyguard to the Roman procurator who resided there.
An ancient coin makes express mention of such a cohort in Syria.
Albert Barnes: Cornelius - This is a Latin name, and shows that the man was doubtless a Roman.
It has been supposed by many interpreters that he was 'a proselyte of the gate'; that is, one who had renounced idolatry, and who observed some of the Jewish rites.
A centurion - One who was the commander of a division in the Roman army, consisting of 100 men.
Marvin Vincent: Italian. Probably because consisting of Roman soldiers, and not of natives of the country.
John Calvin: A rare example that a soldier was so devout towards God, so upright and courteous towards men!

The virtues of Cornelius deserve the greater commendation, in that leading a soldier’s life, which was at that time most corrupt, he served God holily, and lived amongst men without doing any hurt or injury.

Seeing that none of these things could hinder Cornelius, but that forsaking his idols he did embrace the true worship of the true God alone, it must needs be that he was endued with rare and singular sincerity.
Philip Schaff: The work and miracles of Peter at Lydda and elsewhere were the preparation for what is now about to be recounted.
There was something providential, if we may say so, in the fact that Jerusalem never became the Roman capital, but always retained its Hebrew character.
Rather we ought to say that it is a bad thing overruled for good, and made subservient to missionary purposes.
Archibald T. Robertson: These Roman centurions always appear in a favourable light in the N.T.
Furneaux notes the contrasts between Joppa, the oldest town in Palestine, and Caesarea, built by Herod.
The Italian cohorts were sent to any part of the empire as needed.
John Gill: This was the Caesarea formerly called Strato's tower, not Caesarea Philippi; for the former, and not the latter, lay near Joppa.
which was a Roman name, and he himself was a Roman or an Italian.
which consisted of soldiers collected out of Italy, from whence the band took its name, in which Cornelius was a centurion, having a hundred men under him, as the name of his office signifies.

bhtAttempts.bht: Cæsarea, located between Joppa and Dora, was a prominent town in Palestine with both Gentile and Jewish inhabitants. Cornelius, a devout and courteous centurion from the Italian band stationed in Cæsarea, was known for his upright character, despite the corrupt nature of a soldier's life at that time. The virtues of Cornelius were commendable, particularly his sincerity in embracing the true worship of God. His sincere devotion to the true God, forsaking idols, was evident. This account in Acts highlights the providential preparation of Peter's work and miracles in Lydda and elsewhere, as well as the missionary purposes served by the Roman empire's involvement.

Cæsarea, situated between Joppa and Dora, was a sizable town in Palestine with Gentile and Jewish residents. The devout and courteous centurion Cornelius, belonging to the Italian band stationed there, displayed rare and commendable virtues despite the corruption prevalent among soldiers. His sincere and wholehearted embrace of the true worship of God, forsaking idols, was remarkable. This account in Acts highlights the providential preparation of Peter's miraculous work and the missionary purposes served by the involvement of the Roman empire.

Cornelius, a devout centurion from the Italian band stationed there, was known for his sincerity in embracing the worship of the true God while eschewing idols. Despite serving in a corrupt environment as a soldier, Cornelius displayed commendable virtues and treated others with courtesy and upright conduct. The preparation of Peter's work and miracles in Lydda and elsewhere paved the way for the unfolding of this significant event.

The town of Cæsarea, situated between Joppa and Dora, was a notable place with both Gentile and Jewish inhabitants. Cornelius, a centurion from the Italian band stationed in Cæsarea, showcased remarkable virtues despite the corruption typically associated with soldiers. His sincere devotion to the true God and abandonment of idols was truly commendable. This account in Acts showcases the providential preparation of Peter's work and miracles, illustrating the missionary purposes that were fulfilled through the involvement of the Roman empire.

Cæsarea, a notable town built by Herod the Great, was located between Joppa and Dora. As the centurion of the Italian band stationed in Cæsarea, Cornelius, despite the corruption often associated with soldiers, displayed remarkable virtues. His sincere devotion to the true God, forsaking idols, was highly commendable. This account in Acts highlights the providential preparation of Peter's work and miracles, showcasing how the involvement of the Roman empire served missionary purposes.
